The 'grandmother hypothesis' is a theory to explain the existence of menopause,
rare in mammal species, in human life history and how a long post-fertile period
(up to one third of a woman's lifespan) {{cite book |last=Harman |first=S.M.
|coauthors=Talbert, G.B. |year=1985 |chapter=Reproductive aging |title=Handbook
of the Biology of Aging |editors=C. E. Finch and L. Hayflick |pages=457â510
|publisher=Van Nostrand Reinhold}} could confer an evolutionary advantage.

Holding longevity constant, a female that undergoes menopause should have a
lower total fertility rate, making menopause intriguing from an evolutionary
perspective.
